info.game_comments:
2002 College Championship quarterfinal game 1.
From the Schottenstein Center at the Ohio State University in Columbus.

double_jeopardy_round: THERE'S A WHOLE WORLD OUT THERE

(1, 1).clue: Depressed prince can't decide whether to kill nasty uncle until the end of Act V (should have done it sooner)

(2, 1).clue: The Palme d'Or is presented at this French film festival

(3, 1).clue: Born in Massachusetts, she was descended from the Quincy family on her mother's side

(4, 1).clue: The lady on the white horse shows her bling-bling, bros, waving rings on her fingers & these on her toes

(5, 1).clue: Gold-plated pistols used by this female sharpshooter are at L.A.'s Autry Museum of Western Heritage

(6, 1).clue: This word for a time of day comes from the Latin for "ninth hour"

(1, 2).clue: Lady arrives in New Orleans for an extended visit with her sister; her brother-in-law throws a real hissy fit

(2, 2).clue: Past winners of the Pritzker Prize for this include I.M. Pei & Frank Gehry

(3, 2).clue: Seen here, she was one of the wealthiest women in Virginia in 1757

(4, 2).clue: My homeboy Humpty ain't into crack, 'cept when he falls from this right on his back

(5, 2).clue: Seen here, this "beastly" one-time Army scout & Pony Express rider later ran his own Wild West Show

(6, 2).clue: This 7-letter verb can mean to close a meeting, or to meet in another place

(1, 3).clue: Spoiler warning!  We're about to give away the ending!  She throws herself under a train!  In Russia!

(2, 3).clue: This organization awards the Spingarn Medal, its highest honor for achievement among African-Americans

(3, 3).clue: Her uncle lived in the White House when this future first lady got married in 1905

(4, 3).clue: This trio I don't know from Adam can't see the lady with a knife comin' at 'em

(5, 3).clue: Wyatt Earp's brother Morgan survived this 1881 gunfight but was murdered 5 months later

(6, 3).clue: This "animal" verb's synonyms include endure, stand, abide, suffer & support

(1, 4).clue: Swordsman makes guys pay through the (ahem) nose if they dare to mention his incredibly long honker

(2, 4).clue: The Mystery Writers of America named an award for this American, the creator of the detective story

(3, 4).clue: Marvin Pierce, the father of this first lady, was the publisher of McCall's magazine

(4, 4).clue: The best horn player you'll ever see is this hit-the-hay boy, Master LBB

(5, 4).clue: It's the last name shared by brothers Ed, Jim & Bat, all of whom were Old West lawmen

(6, 4).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew reports)  This branch of mathematics deals specifically with the figure seen here

(1, 5).clue: American college professor goes to Spain & blows up a bridge

(2, 5).clue: This foundation, the AFB, gives an award for the narration of talking books

(3, 5).clue: She was a hostess at the White House for the widowed Thomas Jefferson before becoming first lady in 1809

(4, 5).clue: He's the cat who's gone to sea, silver buckles on his knee (shut your mouth) but, I'm talking about...

(5, 5).clue: This lawman tracked down & shot dead the outlaw Billy the Kid

(6, 5).clue: This Italian musical term tells you that you are "obliged" to play a particular part of a piece

(1, 1).clue: This tendon enables muscles at the back of the lower leg to lift the heel when walking or running

(2, 1).clue: Born in Cadiz, he's the sex symbol seen here in the '30s

(3, 1).clue: An incorrectly tied square knot, perhaps tied by your mom's mom

(4, 1).clue: On this day of the month of Shawwal, Muslims begin the festival of breaking the fast

(5, 1).clue: This river is 250 miles longer than the Amazon

(6, 1).clue: Senator Christopher Dodd told UConn grads that the only constant is this

(1, 2).clue: Also called the master gland, it's the most important of the endocrine glands

(2, 2).clue: This "Saturday Night Live" cast member would say yes, she's one of the Shaker Heights Shannons

(3, 2).clue: Guinness reports that in one hour a man tied 833 stems of this fruit into knots with his tongue

(4, 2).clue: Festivals this Scottish city is famous for include a jazz one, a film one & of course, a fringe one

(5, 2).clue: Cape Farewell on this country's South Island is north of Wellington on its North Island

(6, 2).clue: Do this if you're hurrying through life, or if you're passing a florist's aromatic shop

(1, 3).clue: If you've "mapped" out the body, you know it's the topmost cervical vertebra of the neck

(2, 3).clue: This singer of "I Try" & "Why Didn't You Call Me?" originally moved from Ohio to L.A. to learn screenwriting

(3, 3).clue: From the Latin suere, "to sew", it's the thread used to tie knots & stitches during surgery

(4, 3).clue: In January in Michigan people set up shanties on Houghton Lake for a festival devoted to this sport

(5, 3).clue: www.unibo.it is the web address of Europe's oldest university, in this northern Italian city

(6, 3).clue: Speakers compare themselves to the body at this Irish event -- people need you there, but don't expect you to say much

(1, 4).clue: The metatarsal bones are in the foot; these 5 bones lie between the wrist & the fingers

(2, 4).clue: This Cincinnati gal's professional name comes from characters in a film based on a Bizet opera & in a Greek myth

(3, 4).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew reports)  This non-slipping knot takes its name from the line attached to the front part of a boat

(4, 4).clue: Each September the city of Lafayette in this southern state is home to Festivals Acadiens

(5, 4).clue: In a deli, "Hold" this Irish county that features wild coastline & the country's largest bog

(6, 4).clue: This oft-quoted Robert Frost poem says the 2 paths were actually about equally worn

(1, 5).clue: The lowest part of the brain stem, it sits above the spinal cord

(2, 5).clue: In "My City was Gone", this Pretenders singer mourned the Akron of her youth

(3, 5).clue: According to legend, Alexander the Great was unable to untie this knot, so he cut it instead

(4, 5).clue: This Catholic feast on December 8 honors the Virgin Mary

(5, 5).clue: This Asian country with a nomadic tradition has the highest number of horses per capita in the world

(6, 5).clue: You'll be reminded that "Commencement is not" this 3-letter antonym of "commencement"

(0, 0).clue: Physicist John Wheeler compared possible passages through space & time to the work of this creature
